data.title: sse_matrix_math
data.body: SSE optimize Urho3D/Math/Matrix3x4.h and Urho3D/Math/Matrix4.h. These yield a ~3% improvement in 06_SkeletalAnimation sample with 2000 Jacks in it.

data.title: Feature request: Add URHO3D_THREADING CMake option?
data.body: Currently threading is hardcoded to be enabled on all other platforms than Emscripten. It would be useful to have a `URHO3D_THREADING` option, which could be enabled or disabled on all operating systems from the command line (including Emscripten). The default could be to enable on all other platforms than Emscripten. After that one could forcibly disable threading with `URHO3D_THREADING=0` in CMake, for debugging and profiling purposes. I believe the Urho3D task architecture should allow for this kind of scheme?

data.title: opt_node_markdirty
data.body:
Optimize `Node::MarkDirty()` implementation by

a) relying on the invariant that all children of a dirty node must also be dirty, and that all parents of a clean node must also be clean,
b) avoid double-dereferencing Component WeakPtr in listeners,
c) use the swap-with-last erase trick to avoid O(n^2) behavior in removing listeners, and
d) perform tail call optimization to avoid excessive recursive function calls when marking children dirty.

This optimizes the `Node::MarkDirty()` time in 06_SkeletalAnimation scene with 2000 Jacks from 42.73% down to 16.43%, a net saving of -61.5% less time spent in that call site. After this, `Node::MarkDirty()` is no longer the hottest function in the profile, so can say this closes #931.

data.title: Emscripten link warning on file merge.bat in static library.
data.body:
CMake builds for Emscripten are giving this message

```
[ 99%] Linking CXX executable ..\..\..\bin\06_SkeletalAnimation.html
WARNING:root:loading from archive C:\code\Urho3D\build_emcc_sse2\lib\libUrho3D.a
, which has duplicate entries (files with identical base names). this is dangero
us as only the last will be taken into account, and you may see surprising undef
ined symbols later. you should rename source files to avoid this problem (or avo
id .a archives, and just link bitcode together to form libraries for later linki
ng)
WARNING:root:   duplicate: merge.bat
[ 99%] Built target 06_SkeletalAnimation
[100%] Linking CXX executable ..\..\..\bin\12_PhysicsStressTest.html
WARNING:root:loading from archive C:\code\Urho3D\build_emcc_sse2\lib\libUrho3D.a
, which has duplicate entries (files with identical base names). this is dangero
us as only the last will be taken into account, and you may see surprising undef
ined symbols later. you should rename source files to avoid this problem (or avo
id .a archives, and just link bitcode together to form libraries for later linki
ng)
WARNING:root:   duplicate: merge.bat
[100%] Built target 12_PhysicsStressTest
```

That looks like a temporary work file, and it is being put into the generated .a files by accident? (There won't be any problem in the build with this since .bat files don't contain program code, so this is just silly noise)

data.title: approx_quat_slerp
data.body: Optimize Quaternion::Slerp() to remove the costly trigonometric functions and replace them by approximations instead. The approximations have been profiled to generate a maximum interpolation error of 0.38 degrees (see test Quat_Slerp_precision in MathGeoLib). In native 64bit Windows 8.1 VS2015 builds, testing in 06_SkeletalAnimation sample with 2000 Jacks, the time taken in Quaternion::Slerp() is reduced by -17.4%, and in Emscripten build of the same sample running in Firefox 41, the time taken by Quaternion::Slerp() is reduced by -44.7%. Closes #914.

data.title: sse_matrix
data.body:
SSE optimize matrix-matrix multiplications when URHO3D_SSE is enabled. These constitute 7.82% of 06_SkeletalAnimation sample with 2000 Jacks in it. After SSE optimizations applied, matrix multiplication takes only 2.13% of total time in AMD CodeXL profile. This change also seems to have the effect that in scalar version, VS2015 did not dare to inline Matrix3x4 multiplication in AnimatedModel::UpdateSkinning(), but after SSE, the instruction count is small enough that it happily does so.

The code uses explicit unaligned loads and stores as opposed to aligned loads, so that memory layout does not need to change.

Only tested on 06_SkeletalAnimation sample, which uses  `Matrix3x4 operator *(const Matrix3x4& rhs)`. It is possible that the other variants are not tested. Tried to carefully check that the conventions are the same and that the functions are correct - they're adapted from MathGeoLib where they are unit tested.

data.title: emscripten_get_now()
data.body: Code duplication cleanup, and use `emscripten_get_now()` when timing, to get sub-millisecond precision timer results (`gettimeofday` calls to JavaScript `Date.now()`, which has only millisecond precision)

data.title: ANGLE_instanced_arrays
data.body: Add support for GPU hardware instancing on Emscripten. In WebGL 1 it is exposed by the ANGLE_instanced_arrays ( https://www.khronos.org/registry/webgl/extensions/ANGLE_instanced_arrays/ ) extension, and in WebGL 2, it is enabled in core.

Use spine-c's test data spineboy.json in sample 33, If the mouse click happens during the gun firing, the firing will not be destroyed in next animation 
![screenshot from 2015-10-09 19 48 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1681453/10393075/350bb586-6ebf-11e5-984d-05b1d52344d4.png)
![screenshot from 2015-10-09 19 48 34](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1681453/10393080/3ea0c4d8-6ebf-11e5-865f-6ed61091d234.png)

data.title: 42.73% of time is spent in Node::MarkDirty() in 06_SkeletalAnimation sample.
data.body:
Profiling a native Win64 build of `06_SkeletalAnimation` in AMD CodeXL, with the modification that the scene consists of 2000 animated Jack models, the profile looks slightly surprising:

![06_skeletalanimation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/225351/10384533/4453d7c8-6e45-11e5-8c02-b542abca4465.png)

Most of the runtime is spent in marking scene nodes dirty. Taking a closer look, the function profile gives this view:

![06_skeletalanimation_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/225351/10384554/8a502358-6e45-11e5-9b03-d5864be8a95a.png)

which indicates that the weak pointer handling is causing cache misses. What is the listener mechanism used there for? Skinning <-> Scene node interaction? or Skinning <-> Bullet interaction? Or something related? Are weak pointers necessary?

(Sidenote: how large can one expect the `listeners_` array to grow? The `listeners_.Erase(i);` behavior in this function has a O(n^2) complexity when erased in this manner, since `Erase()` shifts all elements back by one, i.e. calling `MoveRange`. although in the captured profile, that does not seem to be an issue here. Using the swap-with-last-element-and-erase-last trick could be used to avoid the quadratic complexity if the order of elements in `listeners_` is not important)

In the `12_PhysicsStressTest` sample with 3000 boxes, the `Node::MarkDirty()` function does show up in the profile as well. Some mitigating strategies if the performance is a concern:
- prefetch the weak pointers in the iteration (if `listeners_` is long)
- pool the weak pointer control blocks and/or listener objects
- implement `Node::MarkDirty()` as iterative instead of recursive, since some time (10% in the profile) is spent in recursively calling child nodes
- remove the weak pointer dependency and make it a strong ref dependency, synchonously/imperatively maintaining pointer removals on both sides of the link?

Not sure if this is a hotspot in any real world scenes, it is possible that 2000 Jacks is just a contrived scenario (feel free to close if so!), but when looking to replace 10kCubes with 10kJacks... ;)

data.title: Bullet 2.83.6
data.body:
This resolves #929.

Cherry-picked the changes from git history to Bullet. The first commit in this pull request is a baseline, which only contains files from upstream bullet and replaces all contents in the previous Source/ThirdParty/Bullet/ directory altogether. The remaining commits play back the different local changes I found either marked with `// Urho3D` in the source tree, or found with git history of Source/ThirdParty/Bullet/.

I do not know if this PR might bring in new regressions from upstream Bullet. Let's hope not. :/

data.title: Consider upgrading to Bullet 2.83.6?
data.body: As part of investigating https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/482 , I upgraded Urho3D Bullet from 2.82 to 2.83.6. I could submit that as a pull request, but before I do so, has there been some specific reason to stick to Bullet 2.82? (it's from October 2013) Would a PR to upgrade to Bullet 2.83.6 be desirable?

data.title: Removing ObjectAnimation and ValueAnimation
data.body:
Currently we can remove a ValueAnimation from an ObjectAnimation using RemoveAttributeAnimation(), or toggle it on/off.
But there is no way to actually remove the ObjectAnimation/ValueAnimation itself or remove a single ValueAnimation created 'outside' of an ObjectAnimation.

data.title: Emscripten Release build passes both -Oz and -O3 linker flags to final link.
data.body:
Building with

```
git clone https://github.com/urho3d/Urho3D.git
cd Urho3D
mkdir build_emscripten
cmake_emscripten.bat build_emscripten -DURHO3D_SAMPLES=1 -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
cd build_emscripten
mingw32-make 12_PhysicsStressTest VERBOSE=1
```

it looks like the final link step comes out as follows:

```
C:\code\emsdk\emscripten\incoming\em++.bat
       -Wno-invalid-offsetof
       -ffast-math
       -m32
       -Wno-warn-absolute-paths
       -Wno-unknown-warning-option
       -Oz
       -DNDEBUG
       -s TOTAL_MEMORY=33554432
       -s USE_SDL=2
       -s NO_EXIT_RUNTIME=1
       -s ERROR_ON_UNDEFINED_SYMBOLS=1
       --shell-file C:/code/Urho3D/build_incoming/Source/shell.html
       --preload-file C:/code/Urho3D/build_incoming/bin/CoreData.pak@/CoreData.pak
       --use-preload-cache
       --preload-file C:/code/Urho3D/build_incoming/bin/Data.pak@/Data.pak
       --use-preload-cache
       -O3
       -s AGGRESSIVE_VARIABLE_ELIMINATION=1
       @CMakeFiles\12_PhysicsStressTest.dir\objects1.rsp
       -o ..\..\..\bin\12_PhysicsStressTest.html
       @CMakeFiles\12_PhysicsStressTest.dir\linklibs.rsp
```

which specifies the two incompatible options `-Oz` and `-O3`. I believe the spec says that the last one takes effect, so the builds come out `-O3` (as desired?). It looks like `-Oz` can be removed. Or was the intent to build with `-Oz`? Generally `-O3` is preferred, so I'm assuming that's the intended one.

data.title: Blank audio is continuously outputted even if application does not have any audio playback.
data.body:
Browsers have gone in a direction where they have an audio speaker icon in each tab indicating whether the tab is generating audio or not. See e.g. http://dottech.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/mute-tab-Firefox.png .

It looks like Urho3D opens the SDL audio device always at startup, which causes the audio playback icon to show up, as the engine is generating and mixing null audio data to the browser. For small Urho3D demos that don't have any audio, this can be a bit confusing if a user is visiting a Urho3D page, and assumes there should some audio since the icon is showing up, but nothing is heard. I wonder if it would make sense to open up the audio device only on demand, e.g. when the playback of first audio clip is started, or some other appropriate spot?

data.title: Add support for detecting ETC1 and PVRTC extensions in Emscripten/WebGL.
Graphics::SetTexture() calls to nonexisting glEnable(GL_TEXTURE_2D) on non-desktop GL.
Use __EMSCRIPTEN__ throughout the codebase instead of EMSCRIPTEN.
data.body:
Historically Emscripten had the `EMSCRIPTEN` #define to signal that the compiler is Emscripten. This was however deemed bad form, since it is outside the namespace of reserved words for compilers according to ISO C standard, so the official predefine has since become `__EMSCRIPTEN__`. It would be better to use that instead of `EMSCRIPTEN` (though I expect `EMSCRIPTEN` will be supported for a long time to come still). To avoid potential breakages in the future, consider using `__EMSCRIPTEN__` instead of `EMSCRIPTEN`.

Also, in a similar fashion, using

```
#include <emscripten/emscripten.h>
```

is considered better form than

```
#include <emscripten.h>
```

to be clear about the include namespace.

data.title: one frame animation is not fully applied
data.body: same as the title, if you have a animation just has one frame, the animation playing looks odd.

data.title: reload script resource dependency not working
data.body:
how to reproduce:
1. using anglescript, the main script file include some other script file,  and assign autoReloadResources=true in script start function.
2. edit and save included script file.
3. game script is not reloaded.
   
   root cause:
   when the main script file is loaded, the autoReloadResources is not assigned yet, so the resource dependency (the include script file) is not added to the dependency map in resource cache.
   
   add a commnd line option to set autoReloadResources flag can solve this problem.

data.title: The default behavior of hiding mouse cursor in windowed mode in Emscripten builds is troublesome.
data.body:
In several samples built for Emscripten, the mouse behavior is a bit quirky. 

What currently happens:
    - mouse cursor is hidden when mouse is moved over the canvas.
    - mouse cursor is restored to be visible again when mouse exits the canvas.
    - moving the mouse over the canvas generates camera mouselook rotate events.
    - moving the mouse outside the canvas does not rotate the camera.
    - mouse cursor is not constrained to stay inside the canvas rectangle, but the mouse cursor is able to freely exit the canvas rectangle.
    - when mouse enters/exits the canvas rectangle, there is an abrupt "discontinuous" snap of the camera lookat direction.

The combination of these behaviors makes looking around the scene by rotating the camera with mouse move a bit difficult, and one can't easily do e.g. a 360 rotation of the . In fullscreen mode, this problem does not occur since the mouse cursor is not able to exit the canvas.

In the 08_decals sample, there is an additional issue that the software mouse cursor rendered by the engine does not match with the location of the actual mouse cursor.

If I might suggest, some ways to come out of the issues:
- remove the behavior of hiding the mouse cursor by default and moving the camera by default, and make it e.g. a "hold down right mouse button to drag" type of gesture.
- In 08_decals sample, one could avoid hiding the mouse cursor over the canvas, but instead let the real mouse cursor stay visible, and not render a software mouse cursor in Urho3D. Then use absolute mouse cursor positions provided by the input api to mark the mouse cursor location instead of calculating them incrementally/relative inside the engine.
- an alternative could be to use the pointer lock api (`emscripten_request_pointerlock()`) when the user clicks on the canvas. Pointer lock hides the mouse cursor on the web page altogether, and changes it to a relative movement mode. See here for a demo http://mdn.github.io/pointer-lock-demo/

data.title: Use emscripten_get_now() instead of gettimeofday() for high-resolution timing.
Frame limiter logic would be better deferred to the browser in Emscripten builds.
data.body:
Looking at a profile of 27_Urho2DPhysics sample, the call to `usleep` function pops up taking 12.2% of total execution time, which is called from `Urho3D::Time::Sleep()`, coming from `Urho3D::Engine::ApplyFrameLimit()`. In browsers, JavaScript code does not have a possibility to run synchronous sleeps themselves, since JS code runs in the same thread than the main browser operates, and such sleeps would block/lock up the browser page DOM/UI for the duration of the sleep. In order to sleep, the code should yield back to the browser. 

Urho3D uses already the `emscripten_set_main_loop_arg()` function to set up the main loop, so the code gets ticks called at 60Hz, or 120Hz, or whichever the native refresh rate of the display is. It sounds like the frame limiter logic could just #ifdeffed out from Emscripten builds since the browser is already limiting the execution rate anyways?

(btw, in the experimental pthreads-capable builds of Emscripten, Emscripten is gaining the support for synchronously sleeping without busy spin-waiting, but that makes sense only in Emscripten `--proxy-to-worker` builds, which are a bit experimental at this point.

data.title: Optimization opportunity: Math.acos() and Math.sin() are relatively slow in Quaternion::Slerp() on Emscripten.
data.body:
Looking at a profile of 06_SkeletalAnimation with the number of skinned models increased to 2000, it looks like browser built-ins `Math.acos` and `Math.sin` called by `Quaternion::Slerp` take up a total of 11.6% of total CPU time spent.

Unfortunately it is difficult to optimize those functions in browser side, one issue being that the browser's hands are tied due to precision guarantees, and that the generic variant must assume unbounded input number, and do range reduction on the input.

On the engine side however, it would be possible to do better manually by exploiting the fact that in slerp, `acos` is ever called with a number in the range `[0,1[`, which allows writing a custom version (LUT, or Lagrange interpolating polynomials are common choices) that's faster for this specific purpose.

data.title: Incremental Emscripten mingw32-make build rebuilds libUrho3D.a even though user did not change it.
data.body:
This is not really a critical issue in any way, but marking down in case it's useful. When building Urho3D sample projects with Emscripten, I'm observing that libUrho3D is rebuilding itself even though I did not do any changes to it.

STR:

```
git clone https://github.com/urho3d/Urho3D.git
cd Urho3D
mkdir build_incoming
cmake_emscripten.bat build_incoming -DURHO3D_SAMPLES=1 -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo
cd build_incoming
mingw32-make
# wait for the full build to finish
# edit Source/Samples/06_SkeletalAnimation/SkeletalAnimation.cpp and change the number of models to draw, e.g. set "const unsigned NUM_MODELS = 2000;" and save the file.
# ask for an incremental rebuild of that sample:
mingw32-make
```

Observed: The build system builds libUrho3D.a as well, with the following print:

```
C:\code\Urho3D\build_incoming>mingw32-make
[  7%] Built target FreeType
[  8%] Built target JO
[  8%] Built target LZ4
[  8%] Built target PugiXml
[  8%] Built target rapidjson
[  8%] Built target SDL
[  8%] Built target StanHull
[  9%] Built target STB
[ 10%] Built target Detour
[ 12%] Built target DetourCrowd
[ 12%] Built target DetourTileCache
[ 14%] Built target Recast
[ 23%] Built target Box2D
[ 47%] Built target Bullet
Scanning dependencies of target Urho3D
[ 47%] Building CXX object Source/Urho3D/CMakeFiles/Urho3D.dir/Resource/JSONFile
.cpp.o
[ 48%] Linking CXX static library ..\..\lib\libUrho3D.a
```

after which it starts to link all samples again (and unfortunately since Emscripten linker is very slow, taking ages :/).

Expected: Changing code in a sample application should not trigger the recompilation of JSONFile.cpp(?), and the build system should only incrementally recompile and relink the 06_SkeletalAnimation project?

data.title: [AngelScript] Please expose BorderImage to Window
FindDirect3D.cmake needs more SDK paths
data.body:
It looks for DirectX redistributables.  It searches some registry paths to locate Windows Kits / SDKs:

find_file (DIRECT3D_DLL NAMES ${DLL_NAMES} PATHS
    "[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Microsoft SDKs\Windows\v8.1;InstallationFolder]/Redist/D3D/${PATH_SUFFIX}"
    "[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Microsoft SDKs\Windows\v8.0;InstallationFolder]/Redist/D3D/${PATH_SUFFIX}"
    NO_DEFAULT_PATH)

However on one of my Windows 10 machines, that started life as a Vista machine and went through a few generations of upgrades of OS and Visual Studio compilers, I have far more than just these 2 kits.  It's got v10.0, v8.1A, v8.1, v8.0A, v8.0, and v7.1A.  They've all got the same path structure, just need more paths.  I would suggest highest number first. 

I have also found v10.0A and v7.0A directories for some binaries, but these aren't listed in the Wow6432Node as part of the SDKs.  Could be a version "gotcha", if directories exist somewhere that don't actually correspond to SDKs.  Just saying, a proper search would have to be careful.

Technically a build should match the Kit actually chosen for the build.  A CMake user has a choice of generators and could have multiple compiler installations living side by side, with different Kits for each.  If such Kits are not being detected though, then figuring this out could get dicey and complicated. I'm not up on CMake methods for detecting "the Kit in use".

 I'm not even sure if these redistributables are actually different from Kit to Kit.  Haven't checked that.
